legacy.description: "This volume is the first book-length examination of Said's remarkable career, providing a critical survey of his writings and an interim assessment of his achievements in both the cultural and political spheres. This collection includes essays on the Arab-Islamic context of Said's work, his reception among Israeli and American Jews, the institutional contexts of his cultural criticism, and his interventions in Middle Eastern politics."

legacy.title: Edward Said and the literary, social, and political world (Publisher: Routledge)
legacy.description: "The contributors to this volume - many among the foremost Edward Said scholars in the world - examine Said as the literary critic, his relationship to other major contemporary thinkers and his involvement with major movements of his time (such as music, feminism, new humanism, and Marxism)."

legacy.title: Edward Said and Critical Decolonization (Publisher: American University in Cairo Press)
legacy.description: "This book is dedicated to Edward Said (1935-2003), a major literary and cultural critic, who has been instrumental in promoting decolonization through his analytical and critical writing. Scholarly articles tackle various aspects of Said's writing on fiction, criticism, politics, and music, and the volume includes an extensive bibliography of Edward Said. Edward Said and Critical Decolonization strives to cover the multifaceted career of Said, with emphasis on his critical contribution to decolonization and resistance to hegemony. There are moving testimonies by friends and relatives, students and colleagues, which throw light on his personality. An article by Said himself on the idea of the university is published here for the first time. The volume also includes articles exploring in depth Said's political, critical, and aesthetic positions--including his views on intellectuals and secular criticism, on traveling theory, and humanism. And Said's thought is explored in relation to other major thinkers such as Freud and Foucault. Contributors: Fadwa Abdel Rahman, Richard Armstrong, Mostafa Bayoumi, Terry Eagleton, Rokus de Groot, Stathis Gourgouris, Hoda Guindi, Ananya Kabir, Lamis El Nakkash, Daisuke Nishihara, Rubén Chuaqui, Yasmine Ramadan, Andrew Rubin, Edward Said, Najla Said, Yumna Siddiqi, David Sweet, Michael Wood, and Youssef Yacoubi."

legacy.title: Edward Said: Legacy of a Public Intellectual (Publisher: Melbourne University Publishing)
legacy.description: "This collection is an enterprise of discovery and critical inquiry into the legacy of one of late modernity's greatest public intellectuals, Edward Said. Noted contributors, including Bill Ashcroft, John Docker, Lisa Lowe, Hsu-ming Teo and Patrick Wolfe, address an array of intellectual, political and cultural issues in their engagement with Said's oeuvre."

legacy.title: Edward Said and the Religious Effects of Culture (Publisher: Cambridge University Press)
legacy.description: "This book provides a distinctive account of Edward Said's critique of modern culture by highlighting the religion-secularism distinction on which that critique is based. Hart explores the connection between this distinction and Said's diverse writings on culture, the true-telling responsibilities of the intellectual, and the Palestinian-Israeli conflict."

legacy.title: Edward Said: the Charisma of Criticism (Publisher: Taylor & Francis)
legacy.description: "This insightful critical biography shows us an Edward Said we did not know. H. Aram Veeser brings forth not the Said of tabloid culture, or Said the remote philosopher, but the actual man, embedded in the politics of the Middle East but soaked in the values of the West and struggling to advance the best European ideas. Veeser shows the organic ties connecting his life, politics, and criticism. Drawing on what he learned over 35 years as Said's student and skeptical admirer, Veeser uses never-before-published interviews, debate transcripts, and photographs to discover a Said who had few inhibit."

legacy.title: The legacy of Edward W. Said (Publisher: University of Illinois Press)
legacy.description: "With the untimely death of Edward W. Said in 2003, various academic and public intellectuals worldwide have begun to reassess the writings of this powerful oppositional intellectual. Figures on the neoconservative right, who have become influential in the policy-making of George W. Bush's administration, have already begun to discredit Said's work as that of a subversive intent on slandering America's benign global image and undermining its global authority. On the left, a significant number of oppositional intellectuals are eager to counter this neoconservative vilification, proffering a Said who, in marked opposition to the "anti-humanism" of the great poststructuralist thinkers who were his contemporaries--Jacques Derrida, Jean-François Lyotard, Jacques Lacan, Louis Althusser, and Michel Foucault--reaffirms humanism and thus rejects poststructuralist theory. In this provocative assessment of Edward Said's lifework, William V. Spanos argues that Said's lifelong anti-imperialist project is actually a fulfillment of the revolutionary possibilities of poststructuralist theory. Spanos examines Said, his legacy, and the various texts he wrote--including Orientalism, Culture and Imperialism, and Humanism and Democratic Criticism--that are now being considered for their lasting political impact."

legacy.title: Edward Said: the paradox of identity (Publisher: Routledge)
legacy.description: "Here is the first comprehensive introduction to Edward Said's literary, political and cultural thinking. Drawing upon Said's journalism as well as his more formal works, Ashcroft and Ahluwalia reveal Said's contemporary significance. While acknowledging the ground breaking significance of Said's Orientalism, this book demonstrates that the key to his work lies in its concept of worldliness and in his demonstration of the paradoxical nature of identity formation in the post-colonial world."

legacy.title: Edward Said and the authority of literary criticism (Publisher: Palgrave Macmillan)
legacy.description: "This book examines the earliest writings of Edward Said and the foundations of what came to be known as postcolonial criticism, in order to reveal how the groundbreaking author of Orientalism turned literary criticism into a form of political intervention. Tracing Said's shifting conceptions of 'literature' and 'agency' in relation to the history of (American) literary studies in the thirty years or so between the end of World War II and the last quarter of the twentieth century, this book offers a rich and novel understanding of the critical practice of this indispensable figure and the institutional context from which it emerged. By combining broad-scale literary history with granular attention to the vocabulary of criticism, Nicolas Vandeviver brings to light the harmonizing of methodological conflicts that informs Said's approach to literature; and argues that Said's enduring political significance is grounded in his practice as a literary critic."

legacy.title: Reading Orientalism: Said and the Unsaid (Publisher: University of Washington Press)
legacy.description: "Goliath, for the critic Edward Said, was Orientalism, the first target of his successive critiques of Western discourse about the Orient, Islam, and Palestinians. By most accounts the rhetorical barbs in his Orientalism brought the giant down to earth, knocked the wind out of a passing generation of academically enshrined windbags, and inaugurated a new intellectual integrity for writ[h]ing against empire. As Gyan Prakash politely phrases it, “Orientalism came as a breath of fresh air to many, but it also left others gasping for breath.” For all its innovative force and in spite of its acknowledged flaws, this single volume..."

legacy.title: A Said dictionary (Publisher: John Wiley & Sons)
legacy.description: "This interpretive dictionary introduces the critical and theoretical world of distinguished literary and cultural critic Edward W. Said through the crucial terms and concepts central to his work. Compares and contrasts Said's perspective with other key theorists, such as Derrida, Spivak, Foucault, and JamesonDescribes the crucial terms and concepts central to Said's workPlaces the development of Said's work within its historical context."

legacy.title: Exiles in the city : Hannah Arendt and Edward W. Said in counterpoint (Publisher: The Ohio State University Press)
legacy.description: "Exiles in the City: Hannah Arendt and Edward W. Said in Counterpoint, by William V. Spanos, explores the affiliative relationship between Arendt's and Said's thought, not simply their mutual emphasis on the importance of the exilic consciousness in an age characterized by the decline of the nation-state and the rise of globalization, but also on the oppositional politics that a displaced consciousness enables. The pairing of these two extraordinary intellectuals is unusual and controversial because of their ethnic identities. In radically secularizing their comportment towards being, their exilic condition enabled them to undertake inaugural critiques of the culture of the nation-state system of Western modernity.""As variations on the theme of exile, the five chapters of this book constitute reflections on what is foundational and abiding in both Arendt's and Said's work. They not only document the heretofore unnoticed affiliation between the two thinkers. They also shed light on Arendt's and Said's proleptic activist explorations of the urgent "question of Palestine," especially on the fraught present situation, which bears increasing witness to the irony that the Israeli nation-state's "solution" has, from the beginning, systematically repeated the degradations the Jewish people suffered at the hands of German nationalism."

legacy.title: The geocritical legacies of Edward W. Said : spatiality, critical humanism, and comparative literature (Publisher: Palgrave Macmillan)
legacy.description: "Edward W. Said remains one of the most important literary and cultural critics in the world. A towering figure in postcolonial studies, Said may be equally well regarded for his scholarship in comparative literature, critical theory, and intellectual history. Less well known, perhaps, is Said's immense influence on geocriticism or spatial literary studies. The Geocritical Legacies of Edward W. Said brings together a variety of essays which, each in its own way, highlight the significance of Said's work for contemporary spatial criticism. With contributions from both established literary critics and emerging scholars, this collection provides a representative sample of work being done in the wake of Said's multifaceted and enormous critical project."

legacy.title: "Edward Said - Annual Memorial Lecture" (Columbia University)
legacy.description:

•	10th Annual Lecture, 2015: Declan Kiberd, "The Future of the Past: Revival Ireland 1891-1922."
•	9th Annual Lecture, 2014: Richard Falk, "The Palestinian Future After Gaza." [Video]
•	8th Annual Lecture, 2013: Raja Shehadeh, "Is There a Language of Peace? Palestine Today and the Categorization of Domination." [Video]

•	6th Annual Lecture, 2011: Ahdaf Soueif, “Notes from the Egyptian Revolution” [Video]

•	1st Annual Lecture, 2005: Daniel Barenboim, “Wagner, Israel, and Palestine.”

legacy.title: "Edward Said - Annual Memorial Lecture" (Australian Friends of Palestina Assocation and the University of Adelaide)
legacy.description: "The annual Edward Said Memorial Lecture, co-hosted by AFOPA and the University of Adelaide, has brought a range of distinguished speakers to Australian audiences since its inauguration in 2005."

legacy.title: "Edward Said Memorial Lecture"
legacy.description:
• 2015: “Palestine and the Anxiety of Existence - Steven Salaita”
• 2016: “Philosophy in Africa - Souleymane Bachir Diagne”
• 2017: “Through the Eyes of Others: Developing Empathy by Reading Fiction - Leila Aboulela”

legacy.title: The 2010 Edward Said Memorial Lecture: "The Palestine Question and the U.S. Public Sphere with Dr. Rashid Khalidi" (The Jerusalem Fund & Palestine Center)
legacy.description: ""The Palestine Question and the U.S. Public Sphere" with Dr. Rashid Khalidi"

legacy.title: The 2011 Edward Said Memorial Lecture: "Palestina: Epicenter of the Arab Revolutions with Dr. Saree Makdisi" (The Jerusalem Fund & Palestine Center)
legacy.description: ""Palestine: Epicenter of the Arab Revolutions" with Dr. Saree Makdisi, Professor of English and Comparative Literature, UCLA."

legacy.title: The 2012 Edward Said Memorial Lecture: "A Deliberate Cruelty: Rendering Gaza Unviable with Dr. Sara Roy" (The Jerusalem Fund & Palestine Center)
legacy.description: "Dr. Sara Roy, Senior Research Scholar in the Center for Middle East Studies at Harvard University is the 2012 Edward Said Memorial Lecture speaker at the Palestine Center. Her talk addresses the political developments of the last decade that have profoundly weakened Gaza and her people, distorting normal economic activity and severely diminishing the productive capacity of the workforce and society. These damaging transformations are becoming institutionalized, shaping a future that is both partial and disfigured. This lecture will examine some of the policies that have brought Gaza to its current state, focusing on their economic and social impact."

legacy.title: The 2013 Edward Said Memorial Lecture: "Looking for Palestine with Ms. Najla Said" (The Jerusalem Fund & Palestine Center)
legacy.description: "The Edward Said Memorial Lecture of 2013 featured speaker Najla Said who presented her latest book, "Looking for Palestine" at the Palestine Center, 2 October 2013."

legacy.title: The 2014 Edward Said Memorial Lecture: "What is the value of Palestinian lives? with Dr. Judith Butler" (The Jerusalem Fund & Palestine Center)
legacy.description: "Dr. Judith Butler, Professor of Comparative Literature & Critical Theory at the University of California, Berkeley, delivers the Edward Said Memorial Lecture at the Palestine Center. Here she discusses the differential value accorded to Palestinian and Israeli lives, in light of the latest IDF military campaign, "Operation Protective Edge" and the untold damage inflicted on the civilian population of Gaza."

legacy.title: The 2015 Edward Said Memorial Lecture: "The Legacy of Edward Said with Dr. Cornel West" (The Jerusalem Fund & Palestine Center)
legacy.description: "As the Palestine Center’s Edward Said Memorial Lecturer this year, Dr. West discusses the profound legacy of Edward Said in social and political thought. He explores Dr. Said’s role as an “engaged intellectual” whose voice provoked introspection, deep questioning, dialogue, and enduring change."

legacy.title: The 2016 Edward Said Memorial Lecture: "The Terrorism Label: an Examination of American Criminal Prosecutions with Wadie Said" (The Jerusalem Fund & Palestine Center)
legacy.description: "As the 2016 Edward Said Memorial Lecturer, Professor Wadie Said confronts the issue of terrorism and the ways in which it is produced and dealt with in the American legal system. In an era in which the phenomenon of Islamophobia has loomed large in public debates about the national security challenges that confront the United States, terrorism laws and prosecutions mirror those debates, but they also raise essential questions as to the sacrificing of constitutional rights and protections that is done in the name of security."

legacy.author_names: Centre for the Humanities - Utrecht University
legacy.title: Edward Said Memorial Conference - "In the Time of Not Yet" with Bettany Hughes, Stathis Gourgouris, Udi Aloni, Marina Warner, Engin Isin, Ariella Azoulay, Paul Gilroy, Robert Nixon, Robert Young, Gayatri Spivak, Ankhi Mukherjee, Jamila Mascat, Akeel Bilgrami, Etienne Balibar, Lila Abu Lughod, Aamir Mufti, Judith Butler, Jan Donner, Mariam Said and Bert van der Zwaan (Centre for the Humanities - Utrecht University)
legacy.description: "Edward Said Memorial Conference was organised by the Centre for the Humanities at Utrecht University as one of the Treaty of Utrecht commemoration events on 15-17 April 2013."

legacy.author_names: Center for Palestine Studies - Edward Said Archive
legacy.title: "Center for Palestine Studies - Edward Said Archive" including archival collection, lectures, memorial lectures, interviews and documentaries, events archive and bibliographies.
legacy.description:
"The Center for Palestine Studies promotes the academic study of Palestine by supporting research, teaching, and intellectual collaboration among scholars within Columbia University and beyond. CPS provides an institutional home for faculty, post-doctoral researchers, and students at Columbia in fields that include history, literary studies, the social sciences, religion, philosophy, law, archaeology, architecture, and the arts. CPS also builds connections with other institutions and scholars to strengthen the academic study of Palestine and Palestinians throughout the United States and the world.
Launched in 2010, the Center for Palestine Studies at Columbia University is the first such center in an academic institution in the United States. The creation of the Center honors the legacy of Professor Edward Said at the university where he taught for forty years. Founded in the City of New York in 1754, and one of the premier research universities in the world, Columbia is the professional home to a concentration of distinguished scholars on Palestine, as well as to an award-winning supporting faculty in a variety of disciplines."

legacy.title: "Assia Djebar : une femme, une oeuvre, des langues : bio-bibliographie, 1936-2009" (Publisher: Éditions Séguier)
legacy.description: "This book attempts to make an inventory of the intellectual production of Assia Djebar, the most famous Algerian writer – and the works on her work from 1957 to 2009. It is therefore about her work at the same time: novels , poetry, drama, as well as short stories, studies and articles published in collective works or periodicals. Also listed are the interviews with the author, and the critical reception of his works, namely theses, essays, books, reviews, etc., as well as press articles that show the importance of his work in the media field beyond. beyond the literary field. This bibliography is intended as a contribution to research in the field of French-language literature. The first version of this book is a critical and commented bibliography of the works of and on Assia Djebar from the publication of her first novel to the present day, and it will be published one day."

legacy.title: "Écrire l’urgence. Assia Djebar et Tahar Djaout" (Publisher: L’Harmattan)
"La diasporisation de la littérature postcoloniale: Assia Djebar, Rachid Mimouni" (Publisher: L’Harmattan)
legacy.description: "In this study, which is as much a matter of literary criticism as of an essay, Hafid Gafaïti draws on the works of Rachid Mimouni and Assia Djebar to explain how, starting from the major upheavals of the 1980s and 1990s, post-literature -colonial has gone from a writing of the nation to a writing of exile and expatriation. The reader will find here references and documents hitherto unknown or impossible to find on the writers studied and on the history of post-colonial North African literature."

legacy.title: "Liberating Shahrazad : feminism, postcolonialism, and Islam" (Publisher: University of Minnesota Press)
legacy.description:
"A long-silenced literary figure speaks for modern Muslim women
Suzanne Gauch analyzes how postcolonial writers and filmmakers from Algeria, Morocco, and Tunisia have reclaimed the storyteller in order to portray Muslim women in ways that highlight their power to shape their own destinies. Gauch demonstrates how these new depictions of Shahrazad from artists such as Fatima Mernissi, Assia Djebar, and Leïla Sebbar reshape the stories told about the Islamic world."

legacy.title: "Feminism and the Question of "Woman" in Assia Djebar's "Vaste est la prison"" in Research in African Literatures 35/4
legacy.description: "This article analyzes the Algerian writer Assia Djebar's uncertain and ambiguous relationship with feminism. While her work is clearly preoccupied with women's experiences, the notion of a collective feminine identity remains a subject of contention, and female characters are frequently presented as both singular and elusive. In Vaste est la prison, the author sets out to trace a coherent genealogy of Algerian women, but the narrative at once hints at and disrupts any clear linking threads. For this reason, I argue that feminist resistance for Djebar revolves not around the uncomplicated celebration of female solidarity, but around a continual shifting between collective and singular critique. Women's resistance to patriarchal oppression in Algeria consists of a continual process of convergence and divergence. Djebar does not propose a single feminist argument but charts instead the very difficult process of creating a shared concrete cause."

legacy.title: "Lectures de Assia Djebar: L'amour, la fantasia, Ombre sultane, La femme sans sépulture" (Publisher: L’Harmattan)
legacy.description: "Three novels by the writer Assia Djebar are treated here according to the method of linear analysis: L'Amour, la fantasia, Ombre sultane, La femme sans sepulture. The reasons for choosing these novels lie in the importance of their major themes: colonization, feminism."

legacy.title: "Language and Space in the Fiction of Assia Djebar and Leila Sebbar" in Research in African Literatures 19/3
legacy.description: "Assia Djebar and Leila Sebbar are leading Francophone women writers whose intent is the same: to express the concerns of Algerian women struggling to break free from their traditional role as mute objects within a rigid patriarchy. In their novels, both writers explore the relationship between écriture, the written word in French and kalaam, the spoken word in Arabic and link it to the concept of public and private space (public = male, private = female). This focus, in part, is personal and autobiographical; they could not have become writers had they not had access to the colonizer's language and schools, to écriture and public space. These advantages, necessary to one's development as a creative writer, were inaccesible to the majority of their Algerian sisters."

legacy.title: "Women Fight, Women Write: Texts on the Algerian War" (Publisher: University of Virginia Press)
legacy.description:
"Today, the "fight to write"—the struggle to become the legitimate chronicler of one’s own story—is being waged and won by women across mediums and borders. But such battles of authorship extend well beyond a single cultural moment.
In her gripping study of unsung female narratives of the Algerian War, Mildred Mortimer excavates and explores the role of women’s individual and collective memory in recording events of the violent anticolonial conflict. Presenting close readings of published works spanning five decades—from Assia Djebar’s 1962 Children of the New World to Zohra Drif’s 2014 Inside the Battle of Algiers: Memoir of a Woman Freedom Fighter— Women Fight, Women Write traces stylistic and material transformations in Algerian women’s writings as it reveals evolving attitudes toward memory, trauma, historical objectivity, and women’s political empowerment. Refuting the stale binary of men in battle, women at home, these testimonial texts let women lay claim to the Algerian War story as participants and also as chroniclers through fiction, historical studies, and memoir.
Algeria’s patriarchal norms long kept women from speaking publicly about private matters, silencing their experiences of the war. Still, the conflict has ceaselessly sparked creative work. The country’s dark decade of violent struggle between the Algerian army and Islamist fundamentalists in the 1990s brought the liberation struggle back into focus, inspiring and emboldening many more women to defiantly write. Women Fight, Women Write advances the broken silence, illuminating its vital historical revisions and literary innovations."

legacy.title: "Assia Djebar" (Publisher: L’Harmattan)
legacy.description: ""For a long time, I believed that writing was to flee, or at least to rush, under this immense sky, in the dust of the road, at the foot of the crumbly dune... For a long time."  This book includes several analyzes by different academics on the work of Assia Djebar. The approach is intended to be global in order to show the scope of all the writings of this woman who was simultaneously a novelist, historian, essayist, short story writer, playwright, poet and filmmaker."

legacy.title: "Assia Djebar, le corps invisible : voir sans être vue" (Publisher: L’Harmattan)
legacy.description: "This work proposes to analyze the path taken by the narrators of L'amour, la fantasia; Vast is the prison; Strasbourg Nights. This journey leads them to move from a passive invisibility of their body, dictated by the patriarchal rules of their society, towards a form of active invisibility, an instrument of resistance against the power of the male gaze, but also the displayed will of the narrators of take ownership of their bodies and their desires. This desire conceals the existential question to which the author tries to answer: What can existence be worth without the possibility of expressing one's desires?"

legacy.title: "Algerian imprints : ethical space in the work of Assia Djebar and Hélène Cixous" (Publisher: Columbia University Press)
legacy.description:
"Born and raised in French Algeria, Assia Djebar and Hélène Cixous represent in their literary works signs of conflict and enmity, drawing on discordant histories so as to reappraise the political on the very basis of dissensus.
In a rare comparison of these authors' writings, Algerian Imprints shows how Cixous and Djebar consistently reclaim for ethical and political purposes the demarcations and dislocations emphasized in their fictions. Their works affirm the chance for thinking afforded by marginalization and exclusion and delineate political ways of preserving a space for difference informed by expropriation and nonbelonging. Cixous's inquiry is steeped in her formative encounter with the grudging integration of the Jews in French Algeria, while Djebar's narratives concern the colonial separation of "French" and "Arab," self and other. Yet both authors elaborate strategies to address inequality and injustice without resorting to tropes of victimization, challenging and transforming the understanding of the history and legacy of colonized space."

legacy.title: "Assia Djebar: Patterns of Resistance" (Columbia University Maison Française)
legacy.description: "The death of the Algerian writer and filmmaker Assia Djebar in February 2015 represents the loss of a major voice of world literature and one of the last great literary representatives of the age of decolonization. For half a century, Djebar explored her country’s past and present in novels, essays and films that combine poignant lyricism with theoretical sophistication. Counter-narratives to official nationalism, her works highlight the experiences of Algerian women before, during and after colonialism. In this one-day conference, an international group of leading scholars reflect on Djebar’s poetics, politics and legacies."

legacy.title: "Assia Djebar, entre ombre et soleil" (CBA documentary channel)
legacy.description: "Discovery of Algeria with Assia Djebar, writer and historian, a woman brought up between two worlds, the French school and the Arab-Andalusian patio. An encounter to question the present of this society in crisis where the role of women has become a political issue."

legacy.title: "Assia Djebar, au coeur des mots" (Director: Florida Sadki)
legacy.description: "Interview taken from the documentary "Asia Djebar, at the heart of words" directed by Florida Sadki in 1990"

legacy.author_names: Eugenia Grammatikopoulou, Dr. Katerina Spiropoulou & Dr. Andreas Papanikolaou (Université Aristote de Thessalonique & Institut Français de Thessalonique)
legacy.title: "Symposium « Des écrits de femmes enterrés » Colloque international à la mémoire d’Assia Djebar"
legacy.description:
"As part of the conference " Women in struggle ", on March 8, 1990 in Fez, Assia Djebar began her speech with the following sentence: " For Arab women, I believe that we have ensured, for about 14 centuries, that women's writings are buried, erased, suppressed and, my God, as for the words, we put forward much more often, I would say, the most mournful words, of those who cry, of those who are in mourning and not so much of those who claim, those who oppose and those who stand up".
Far from being buried, the writings of Assia Djebar knew, well before her disappearance in 2015, an important echo. Nevertheless, the line of force that runs through her texts is her desire to give voice to other women, to those who have been deprived of speech by all kinds of arbitrarily imposed male sovereignty. While the first works of Assia Djebar evoke the struggle of women on a daily basis, their confinement in traditional Algerian society, their lack of communication with the outside world and their desire for emancipation, her theme gradually opens up to a wide range of subjects who, without ever denying it, go beyond the ethnic, linguistic and cultural identity of their origins.
The purpose of this symposium is to pay tribute to the literary and critical contribution of this first writer from the Maghreb to be received at the French Academy (in 2005) without limiting itself to the Franco-Algerian postcolonial universe. If Assia Djebar rightly remarks that the female voice of protest was traditionally gagged among her compatriots, this practice of muzzling largely transcends the Eastern space. For, despite progress towards gender equality and the proven achievements of parity, even in the West of the 21st century, female expression that does not conform to the tone of decay and sentimentality considered decent for the "weaker sex" is likely to be overlooked."

legacy.title: "In Memoriam: Assia Djebar (1936-2015)" (Duke Franklin Humanities Institute)
legacy.description: "World renowned feminist novelist, Assia Djebar was inducted into the Académie Française in 2005. Djebar’s numerous works paint the canvas of Algeria’s tumultuous history from the French invasion in 1830 to the civil war of the late 1990s."

legacy.title: "The Assia Djebar Novel Prize"
legacy.description: "The Assia Djebar Novel Prize was created in 2015. It is an Algerian literary prize to promote Algerian literary production in Arabic, Amazigh (Berber), and French"

legacy.title: "L'aventure Althusser – A documentary with interviews with Pierre Macherey, Etienne Balibar, Jacques Rancière" (Icarus Films Release)
legacy.description:
"Philosopher, Marxist, professor, murderer. More than a quarter century after his death, Louis Althusser, one of the most influential leftist thinkers of the 20th century, remains an enigmatic figure: a man whose work rejuvenated Marxist theory through books such as For Marx and Reading Capital, a Communist who strove to create a new framework following the revelations of Stalinist terror... and a victim of mental illness who, in his darkest moment, strangled his wife of more than 30 years.
ALTHUSSER, AN INTELLECTUAL ADVENTURE traces the development of Althusser's thought, which influenced a who's who of French philosophers, including Lacan, Foucault, Derrida, and Barthes. Credited with reinterpreting Marx in a way that encouraged readers to engage directly with his work, Althusser brought the Freudian concept of overdetermination to Marxist theory, and argued that Marx's work should not be read as one consistent whole, because there was a clear 'break' between his earlier and later writings. But Althusser's most enduring contribution may be the concept of ideological state apparatuses: institutions and social structures including schools, churches, and families, that serve to reinforce the capitalist state.
ALTHUSSER, AN INTELLECTUAL ADVENTURE captures the man, and the implications of his work, in interviews with friends and colleagues such as Lucien Seve, who served more than 30 years on the central committee of the Communist Party of France, and with philosophers and former students including Etienne Balibar, Pierre Macherey, and Jacques Ranciere."

legacy.author_names: Ann Laura Stoler, Stathis Gourgouris and Jacques Lezra (eds.)
legacy.title: "Thinking with Balibar: a Lexicon of Conceptual Practice" (Publisher: Fordham University Press)
legacy.description:
"This volume, the first sustained critical work on the French political philosopher Étienne Balibar, collects essays by sixteen prominent philosophers, psychoanalysts, anthropologists, sociologists, and literary critics who each identify, define, and explore a central concept in Balibar’s thought. The result is a hybrid lexicon-engagement that makes clear the depth and importance of Balibar’s contribution to the most urgent topics in contemporary thought.
The book shows the continuing vitality of materialist thought across the humanities and social sciences and will be fundamental for understanding the philosophical bases of the contemporary left critique of globalization, neoliberalism, and the articulation of race, racism, and economic exploitation.
Contributors: Emily Apter, Étienne Balbar, J. M. Bernstein, Judith Butler, Monique David-Ménard, Hanan Elsayed, Didier Fassin, Stathis Gourgouris, Bernard E. Harcourt, Jacques Lezra, Patrice Maniglier, Warren Montag, Adi Ophir, Bruce Robbins, Ann Laura Stoler, Gary Wilder"

legacy.title: "Balibar and the Citizen Subject" (Publisher: Edinburgh University Press)
legacy.description:
"Explores the core of Balibar’s work since 1980
This collection explores Balibar’s rethinking of the connections between subjection and subjectivity by tracing the genealogies of these concepts in their discursive history. The 12 essays provide an overview of Balibar’s work after his collaboration with Althusser. They explain and expand his framework; in particular, by restoring Arabic and Islamic thought to the conversation on the citizen subject. The collection includes two previously untranslated essays by Balibar himself on Carl Schmitt and Thomas Hobbes.
Key Features
The first English-language edited collection to focus on Balibar
Presents and explains Balibar’s key contributions to political theory and the history of political philosophy
Includes two essays by Balibar himself on Carl Schmitt and Thomas Hobbes: 'Schmitt’s Hobbes, Hobbes’s Schmitt' and 'The Mortal God and his Faithful Subjects: Hobbes, Schmitt and the Antinomies of Secularism'
Contributors include Étienne Balibar, Nancy Armstrong, Giorgos Fourtounis, Mohamed Moulfi"

legacy.title: "READ THE MASKS. TRADITION IS NOT GIVEN" (van Abbe Museum)
legacy.description: "‘Read the Masks. Tradition Is not Given’ by artists Annette Krauss and Petra Bauer. The film questions the Dutch tradition of Zwarte Piet in the light of its social and political implications and caused much upheaval in 2008 when it was showed as part of the exhibition ‘Be(com)ing Dutch’ at the van Abbe museum in Eindhoven."

legacy.title: "Verhalen uit her queer-archief: Gloria Wekker" (Publisher: With Pride)
legacy.description: "Gloria Wekker is an Afro-Surinamese professor emeritus, and she occupied the Aletta Chair in Gender and Ethnicity (established by the IIAV-now Atria) at the Faculty of Humanities of Utrecht University between 2001 and 2012. Wekker is a social and cultural anthropologist, and is a specialist in Gender Studies, Sexuality Studies, African American Studies, and Caribbean Studies. Her most recent book is White Innocence: Paradoxes of Colonialism and Race published in English by Duke University Press and in Dutch by Amsterdam University Press. Wekker previously published the internationally renowned book The Politics of Passion: Women's Sexual Culture in the Afro-Surinamese Diaspora. Together with Maayke Botman and Nancy Jouwe, Wekker put together Kaleidoscopic visions: the black, migrant – refugee women's movement in the Netherlands. The book is the only publication on the ZMV movement."

legacy.title: "Strange Fruits: Queer of Color Intellectual Labor in the Netherlands in the 1980s and 1990s" in Postcolonial Intellectuals in Europe Critics, Artists, Movements, and their Publics by Sandra Ponzanesi and Adriano José Habed (eds.)
legacy.description: "This chapter offers a portrait of postcolonial queer of color formations emerged in the Netherlands through the 1980s and 1990s, paying specific attention to the nature of their intellectual labor. In the first section of the chapter, we sketch the conditions of emergence of Sister Outsider and Strange Fruit and we discuss the nature of their collective intellectual labor, including the work of translation. Hence, in the second and third sections, we offer brief portraits of two activist intellectuals: Andre Reeder of Strange Fruit and Gloria Wekker of Sister Outsider. We turn to Reeder and Wekker to complicate any simple account of collective intellectual labor. On the one hand, it is essential that we recognize the intellectual labor performed by collectives and movements themselves; and that we disarticulate, at least in part, the function of public intellectuality from the work of exceptional individuals. This is one of the central merits of this volume and one of the aims of our chapter. On the other hand, we maintain that it would be reductive to overlook the multiple interactions between collectives and intellectuals, and that the focus on collective intellectual labor should not write off the contributions of key intellectual figures. The stories of Sister Outsider and Strange Fruit, at least, suggest that the dialectic between political collectives and activist intellectuals is part and parcel of the intellectual labor performed by social movements."

legacy.title: "Can the Archive Speak? Mapping Feminist and Queer Genealogies of Colour in The Netherlands" (PhD dissertation)
legacy.description: "This thesis examines the everyday experiences of people active within the Black, Migrant and Refugee (BMR) Movement (1980 – 2000s) in the Netherlands and the role of the archive therein. Based on sixteen months of multi-site archival research and interviews conducted with women active within the BMR Movement, I argue that practices and everyday manifestations of diasporic kinship, intimacy and queer forms of care inform and shape this intricate network of connections and exchanges. These articulations of belonging and creative interruptions trouble dominant ideas about race, sexuality and place in the wider Dutch context. The thesis includes an analysis of three significant BMR collectives, Flamboyant, Sister Outsider and Strange Fruit, to investigate everyday political experiences using the following themes: spatiality and belonging, transnational feminist exchange, intimacy and kinship, and queer of colour politics and cultural work. Subsequently, I provide two broader thematic contemplations on care and futurity addressing the ghosts, hauntings and queer aesthetics within the archive. By examining how archives are used, this project moves away from centring the archive as an end-goal for feminist and queer organising and emphasises the tensions in archival practice, memorialization, non-narrativity, and language that are embedded in the making of a BMR genealogy. Overall, I argue that the BMR movement does not constitute an ‘alternative’ or ‘counter-archive’, but rather disrupts what becomes legible as archive."

legacy.title: "Alledaags Racisme" (Publisher: Feministische Uitgeverij Sara)
"Paul Gilroy" (Publisher: Routledge)
legacy.description:
"Paul Gilroy has been a controversial force at the forefront of debates around race, nation, and diaspora. Working across a broad range of disciplines, Gilroy has argued that racial identities are historically constructed, formed by colonization, slavery, nationalist philosophies, and consumer capitalism.
Paul Williams introduces Gilroy’s key themes and ideas, including:
the essential concepts, including ethnic absolutism, civilizationism, postcolonial melancholia, iconization, and the ‘black Atlantic’
analysis of Gilroy’s broad-ranging cultural references, from Edmund Burke to hip-hop
a comprehensive overview of Gilroy’s influences and the academic debates his work has inspired.
Emphasizing the timeliness and global relevance of Gilroy’s ideas, this guide will appeal to anyone approaching Gilroy’s work for the first time or seeking to further their understanding of race and contemporary culture."

legacy.title: "In Search of ‘Other Londons’: A Bend in the River by Caryl Phillips and Johny Pitts" in Journal for Literary and Intermedial Crossings 4
legacy.description: "This article focuses on two recent representations of postcolonial London, namely the essay “A Bend in the River” (2013) by Caryl Phillips and his collaboration with photographer Johny Pitts on the multimedia slideshow A Bend in the River (2012). Both works hybridize traditional notions of London purported in 20th-century London fictions, which tend to concentrate on the city’s iconic centre without mentioning its history of religious and (neo-)colonial exploitation. The analysis explores how spoken texts, photographs and sound recordings interact in the slideshow and scrutinizes the crucial role that intertextual references to Conrad, Eliot and Selvon play in both works, marking a resistance to historical preconceptions. Finally, a discussion of symbolic, imaginary and documentary dimensions of space will show how the use of different expressive media brings the multi-layered experience of being Black in London to the fore."

legacy.title: Filmography "Johny Pitts"
legacy.description: "Johny Pitts is an actor, known for The Johnny and Inel Show (2013), All Over the Place: Asia (2017) and All Over the Place: Asia Part 2."

legacy.title: "Afroeuropean Studies in Perspective" in Hungarian Journal of English and American Studies 24/2
legacy.description: "In recent years, the field of Afroeuropean studies has emerged as a significant and  innovative  area  of  scholarly  and  critical  inquiry,  drawing  on  academic research  with  equal force  in  the  humanities  and  social  sciences,  social  and political  interventions,  and  overlapping  and  often-shifting  networks  of individuals, institutions, and discourses. Based on the increasingly critical need to  open  up  the  study  of  African  identity,  writ  large,  in  evolving  European spaces, Afroeuropean studies crosses geographical and historical boundaries which  have  become  more  and  more  challenged  through  the  experiences  of migration,  dislocation,  and  diaspora."

legacy.title: "#RivetingReviews: John Saul Reviews AFROPEAN: NOTES FROM BLACK EUROPE by Johny Pitts" (Publisher: European Literature Network)
legacy.description: "Johny Pitts’ splendid reportage manages to be both engaging and disturbing. He makes contact with black Europeans in several major cities and in Afropean recounts their experiences, often in their own words. A flavour of the author: ‘Labels are invariably problematic … but at their best they can sing something into visibility.’ Given that the word ‘European’ is still commonly used as a synonym for ‘white’, invisibility is a common theme. Throughout the countries Pitts visits, black people working at night – cleaning, making deliveries or guarding buildings – are in the daytime nowhere to be seen. Whether born in a country or on their ‘migratory path across cultures, generations and geography’, when people’s backgrounds and experiences do come to light they are naturally and invariably highly complicated."

legacy.title: "Other Europes" in Soundings: A journal of politics and culture 72
legacy.description: "Europe has voted. Yet much remains unclear after the 2019 European Parliament elections-which may or may not have been Britain's last. While Farage's Brexit Party achieved the highest result (31.6 per cent), votes for outspokenly pro-EU parties added up to 40.4 per cent (the combined outcome of votes for Liberal Democrats, Greens, SNP, Plaid Cymru and Change UK). A similar trend was visible across the continent: traditionally centrist parties lost votes to both Greens and progressives, as well as to parties mobilising on xenophobic rhetoric, including in Italy and France, where Marine Le Pen's far-right list overtook Emmanuel Macron's."

legacy.title: "Johny Pitts Afropean: Notes from Black Europe" in Annales: Histoire, Sciences Sociales 76/4

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Date of birth
events.description: Gramsci was born in Ales, Sardinia, Italy on January 22nd.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Early life
events.description: When Gramsci was 9, Gramsci’s father, a public official, was sentenced to five years of imprisonment having been accused of embezzlement and corruption. Gramsci’s childhood was profoundly affected by this event, as the family was deprived of income, and his mother had to work non-stop to support them.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Early life
events.description: Gramsci started working at a young age, for 10 hours a day, to help contribute to the family’s finances.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Enrolled in University
events.description: After being awarded a highly competitive nation-wide scholarship for poor students from all over the new Kingdom of Italy, Gramsci enrolls in the Faculty of Letters and Philosophy at the University of Turin, with a course of study in Modern Philology, Italy. But the funds were not enough to support him and he suffered much deprivation and poverty. He met Palmiro Togliatti, future leader of the Italian Communist Party, at the University of Turin as well, and they formed a life-long political collaboration and friendship.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Started working as a journalist and political activist
events.description: Gramsci completed his last exam at the University and then began a different career as a journalist and political activist. He was already a member of the Italian socialist party, which included Benito Mussolini.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Position at socialist paper Il Grido del Popolo
events.description: Gramsci began working as a full-time journalist for the socialist paper Il Grido del Popolo (The Cry of the People) in Turin.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Wrote famous article
events.description: In the year of the Russian Revolution, which saw the establishment of a new communist form of government in Russia, Gramsci wrote a famous article in which he gave a wide-ranging interpretation of Marxism that was more historically attuned to reality than that of his contemporary Amadeo Bordiga.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Co-founds L’Ordine Nuovo
events.description: In Turin, Gramsci co-founds L’Ordine Nuovo, a publication that aimed to disseminate Marxist ideas and praxis in Italy. It became the vehicle of political debate around the possibilities for communist revolution and as per Gramsci’s thought, it aimed to connect national revolutionary movements with international and global Marxism. It turned into a daily paper soon after its foundation.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Offered key theoretical inspiration for the Factory Councils
events.description: Gramsci offered the key theoretical inspiration for the Factory Councils, run by workmen, that took over several factories in northern Italy and were modelled on the Russian Soviets. The aim of the factory councils was to promote mass revolution and they gathered workers of all political stripes on the left, from anarchists to socialists. Their broad position was supported by the Third Communist International and by Lenin. But these ultimately failed to bring about the national insurrection that had led to the Russian Revolution. Gramsci was on the other side of the political debate that split the young Italian Marxist movement, and whose protagonists were Amadeo Bordiga and other socialists who did not agree with the broad church of the factory councils promoted by the Gramscian branch of the party. Gramsci subsequently acknowledged that Italy was probably not ready for revolution a that point in time.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Founding of the Italian Communist Party
events.description: Gramsci was instrumental in founding the Italian Communist Party, known back then as Il Partito Comunista d’Italia (the Communist Party of Italy).

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Became Representative of the Italian Communist Party and met wife
events.description: Gramsci was sent to Moscow as the Representative of the Italian Communist Party. This experience was fundamental to the maturing of his political formation. He met his future wife, Giulia Schucht, and they had a child together. In 1922, Mussolini established the fascist regime in Italy and Italian Communist activists got more and more targeted. He was charged by Moscow to sew back together the factions in the Italian revolutionary movement.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Travelled to Vienna
events.description: Gramsci travelled from Moscow to Vienna, having become the foremost Italian political leader in the Italian communist party.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Return to Italy, elected as an MP
events.description: Gramsci returned to fascist Italy, where he had been elected an MP of the Italian Communist Party.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Banning of Italian Communist Party and imprisonment
events.description: The Italian Communist Party was banned by the fascist regime, and its main proponents went to exile in France. Gramsci continued to live in Rome. He was the main author of the Party’s “Theses of Lyon”, supporting democratic unity within the party and developing an international strategy for the party. In that same year, Gramsci was imprisoned by the regime and sent to the Ara Coeli prison in Rome. He was then sent to be imprisoned in Ustica, an island off the coast of Sicily. He spent 44 days there. He began to serve a 20-year prison sentence in Turi, Apulia. At his trial, Gramsci’s prosecutor famously said: “We must stop this brain from functioning for twenty years.” He spent 11 years in prison.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Campaign to release Gramsci
events.description: Many prominent Italian and international intellectuals campaigned to release Gramsci from prison. In the meantime, his health deteriorated drastically.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Moved to a clinic
events.description: In 1933, Gramsci was moved from the prison at Turi to a clinic at Formia, but was still denied adequate medical attention.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Moved to a clinic
events.description: Gramsci was moved to the Quisisana clinic in Rome due to ill-health.

events.author: Antonio Gramsci
events.title: Due for release and date of death
events.description: Gramsci was due for release on 21 April 1937, but due to a combination of severe health conditions, he died on April 27th, 1937, at the age of 46. His ashes are buried in the Cimitero acattolico (Non-Catholic Cemetery) in Rome.

events.author: Frantz Fanon
events.title: Move to Blida, Algeria
events.description: Fanon moved to Algeria and became appointed chef de service in psychiatry at Blida-Joinville Hospital in Algeria.

events.author: Frantz Fanon
events.title: Joining of the Front de Libération Nationale
events.description: Fanon joined the Front de Libération Nationale (FLN) during outbreak of the Algerian revolution in November 1954. He became responsible for treating the psychological distress of the French soldiers and officers who carried out torture in order to suppress anti-colonial resistance and responsible for treating Algerian torture victims.

events.author: Frantz Fanon
events.title: Appointed Ambassador to Ghana by Algeria’s FLN-led Provisional Algerian Government (GPRA) and diagnosed with leukemia
events.description: Fanon was appointed Ambassador to Ghana by Algeria’s FLN-led  Provisional Algerian Government (GPRA) and attended conferences in Accra, Conakry, Addis Ababa, Leopoldville, Cairo and Tripoli. In the same year, upon returning to Tunesia, Fanon was diagnosed with leukemia. He travelled to the Soviet-Union for treatment.

events.author: Frantz Fanon
events.title: Return to Tunesia, and treatment in the US
events.description: Fanon returned to Tunesia and delivered lectures to the Armée de Libération Nationale (ALN) officers at Ghardimao on the Algerian-Tunisian border and travelled to Rome for a three-day meeting with Jean-Paul Sartre. He later received treatment for his leukemia in the US.

events.author: Frantz Fanon
events.title: Date of death
events.description: Fanon died December 6, 1961 in Bethesda, Maryland, U.S. at a National Institutes of Health facility. He was later buried in  in the border village Ain El-Kerma, in El Taref Province, eastern Algeria.

events.author: Zygmunt Bauman
events.title: Date of birth
events.description: Bauman was born in Poznan, Poland on November 19th.

events.author: Zygmunt Bauman
events.title: Enlisted in the First Polish Army
events.description: Bauman Bauman enlisted in the Soviet-controlled First Polish Army in the 1940s and worked as a political instructor. He took part in the Battle of Kolberg (1945) and the Battle of Berlin. He was awarded the Military Cross of Valour in May 1945.

events.author: Zygmunt Bauman
events.title: Complete Master's degree
events.description: Bauman completed his Master's degree at the Warsaw Academy of Political and Social Science.

events.author: Zygmunt Bauman
events.title: Became lecturer and Professor
events.description: Bauman was lecturer then professor at the University of Warsaw.

events.author: Zygmunt Bauman
events.title: New position
events.description: Bauman went to Tel Aviv, Israel to teacht at Tel Aviv University.

events.author: Zygmunt Bauman
events.title: New position
events.description: Bauman left Israel and accepted the chair of sociology at the University of Leeds, where he intermittently also served as head of the department.

events.author: Zygmunt Bauman
events.title: Won the Amalfi Prize
events.description: Bauman received the Amalfi Prize for Sociology and Social Sciences.

events.author: Zygmunt Bauman
events.title: Won the Theodor Adorno Award
events.description: Bauman received the Theodor Adorno Award.

events.author: Zygmunt Bauman
events.title: Won the Prince of Asturias award for the Humanities
events.description: Bauman received (jointly with Alain Touraine) the Prince of Asturias award for the Humanities.

events.author: Zygmunt Bauman
events.title: ‘The Bauman Institute’ was created
events.description: In Bauman's honor, the University of Leeds created  ‘The Bauman Institute’ within the School of Sociology and Social Policy.

events.author: Zygmunt Bauman
events.title: Date of death
events.description: Bauman died on January 9th, in Leeds, UK.

events.author: Stuart Hall
events.title: Date of birth
events.description: Hall was born in Kingston, Jamaica on February 3rd.

events.author: Stuart Hall
events.title: Move to the Oxford, UK
events.description: Hall moved to Oxford, UK and became Rhodes scholar at Merton College.

events.author: Stuart Hall
events.title: Move to Birmingham, UK
events.description: Hall moved to Birmingham, UK and joined the Birmingham Centre for Contemporary Cultural Studies.

events.author: Stuart Hall
events.title: Move to London, UK
events.description: Hall left Birmingham for London and became Professor of Sociology at the Open University.

events.author: Stuart Hall
events.title: Position Iniva and Autograph ABP
events.description: Hall became Chair at Iniva and Autograph ABP until 2008.

events.author: Stuart Hall
events.title: Date of death
events.description: Hall died in London, UK on February 10th.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Date of birth
events.description: Said was born in Jerusalem on November 1st.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Early life
events.description: Said was born in Jerusalem into a Christian family. His father, Wadie (William) Ibrahim, was a wealthy businessman who had spent years in America. His mother, Hilda Said, was an Arab Christian. Said had four sisters whose names were Rose, Jane, Joyce, and Grace. Said's father had moved from Jerusalem in 1929 and established a stationary company, and Said got his early education in Cairo.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Left Jerusalem
events.description: Said's family left Jerusalem and moved to Cairo to avoid the conflict beginning over Palestine’s partition into separate Arab and Jewish areas.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Attended Victoria College
events.description: Said attended Victoria College, a British colonial school designed to educate the ruling class, in Cairo.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Received bachelor's degree
events.description: Said attended Princeton University and got his B.A. degree.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Received master's and PhD degree
events.description: Said attended Harvard University and got his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees in English literature.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Became lecturer
events.description: Said became a lecturer in English at Columbia University, New York.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Published first book
events.description: Said's first book, Joseph Conrad and the Fiction of Autobiography (1966), was an expansion of his doctoral thesis.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: New position
events.description: Said was promoted to Assistant Professor of English and comparative literature.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Became Professor
events.description: Said was promoted to full professor. He held this position at Columbia University until the end of his life.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Married
events.description: Said married Mariam Cortas in 1970, by whom he had a son and a daughter (Wahid and Najla).

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Became a member of the Palestinian National Council
events.description: Said became a member of the Palestinian National Council.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Favored a two-state solution
events.description: Said favored a two-state solution, with Israel and a Palestinian state existing side by side.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Negotiations on the Palestinians' behalf with U.S. Secretary of State
events.description: Said was sent by Arafat to negotiate on the Palestinians' behalf with U.S. Secretary of State George Shultz.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Diagnosed with leukemia
events.description: In the early 1990s Said was diagnosed with leukemia but was able to continue his public activities after treatment. One of several books published after Said's death (he wrote voluminously during his final years) was On Late Style (2006), an examination of works produced by literary and musical artists toward the ends of their lives.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Resigned from the Palestinian National Council
events.description: Said resigned from the Palestinian National Council.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Co-founded the East West Divan Orchestra
events.description: Said and conductor Daniel Barenboim co-founded the East West Divan Orchestra, a joint Israeli-Palestinian youth ensemble that continued to win acclaim after Said's death.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Won the Lifetime Achievement Award by the Lannan Foundation
events.description: Among the literary awards Said received in his last years was one for Lifetime Achievement, bestowed by the Lannan Foundation in 2001.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Medical condition worsened
events.description: Said's medical condition worsened in 2002, and he worked against the clock to finish several new books, including On Late Style, From Oslo to Iraq, the Road Map , and Humanism and Democratic Criticism. All were published after his death.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Published a compilation of conversations with Barenboim
events.description: Said and Barenboim worked on numerous other projects together and, in 2002, published Parallels and Paradoxes: Explorations in Music and Society, a compilation of their public conversations on music.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Date of death
events.description: Said died from leukemia in New York on September 25th.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Received prize
events.description: Said received the Bowdoin Prize by Harvard University in 1960.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Became laureate
events.description: Said was honored with the Spinoza Lens by the International Spinoza Award Foundation in 1999.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Received award
events.description: Said won the Lionel Trilling Book Award by Columbia University in 1976.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Received award
events.description: Said was awarded the Wellek Prize of the American Comparative Literature Association from The American Comparative Literature Association in 1984.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Received award
events.description: Said received Al Owais Award for 1996–97 from Sultan Bin Ali Al Owais.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Became laureate
events.description: Said received the Prince of Asturias Award for Concord along with Daniel Barenboim by the The Princess of Asturias Foundation in 2002.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Received honorary doctorate
events.description: Said received numerous honorary doctorates. Among them, he was most proud of the one he received in 1993 from Birzeit University.

events.author: Edward Said
events.title: Elected as member of the American Academy of Arts & Sciences
events.description: Said was elected as a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1991.

events.author: Frantz Fanon
events.title: Date of birth
events.description: Fanon was born in Fort-de-France, Martinique on July 20th.

events.author: Frantz Fanon
events.title: Wounded during military service
events.description: Fanon was wounded in Colmar, France, while fighting with the Free French Forces. He received a Croix de guerre. Fanon and fellow Afro-Caribbean soldiers were sent to Toulon (Provence) , and after that to Normandy to await repatriation.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Date of birth
events.description: Djebar was born in Cherchell, Algeria on June 30th.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Enrolled in school
events.description: Djebar attends school in Algiers and Blida, and follows the “khâgne” (two-year academic program in the French undergraduate system) in Paris in 1954.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Enters the École normale supérieure de jeunes filles
events.description: As the first Algerian woman, Djebar enters the École normale supérieure de jeunes filles in Sévres, France in 1955, where she specializes in history.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Participates in student strikes
events.description: Djebar participates in the student strikes against French repression in Algeria in 1956 and she is evicted from school.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Publishes first novel
events.description: Djebar publishes her first novel, La Soif ("The Thirst").

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Starts to teach history
events.description: Djebar teaches history at the Faculty of Letters at the University of Rabat.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Teaches literature and cinema
events.description: Djebar teaches literature and cinema at the University of Algiers.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Becomes professor
events.description: Djebar becomes professor at Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: New position
events.description: Djebar becomes professor at New York University where she holds the Silver Chair Professorship.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Directs her first film
events.description: Djebar directed her first film, La Nouba des Femmes du Mont Chenoua.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Elected to the Académie Française
events.description: Djebar is elected to the Académie Française, the prestigious French institution.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Won the the International Critics' Prize
events.description: Djebar won the International Critics' Prize at the Venice Biennale, for La Nouba des Femmes du Mont Chenoua.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Won the Neustadt International Prize for Literature
events.description: Djebar won the Neustadt International Prize for Literature.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Becomes  Grand Officer of the Legion of Honour and and Commandeur des Arts et des Lettres
events.description: Djebar became Grand Officer of the Legion of Honour and and Commandeur des Arts et des Lettres.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Married
events.description: Djebar married the Algerian theatre man and resistance fighter Walid Garn (Ahmed Ould-Rouis).

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Divorced
events.description: Djebar divorces Walid Garn (Ahmed Ould-Rouis).

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Married
events.description: Djebar married the writer and director Malek Alloula.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Divorced
events.description: Djebar divorces Malek Alloula.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Adopts a son
events.description: Djebar adopts a son, Mohamed Garne.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Adopts a daughter
events.description: Djebar adops a daughter, Djalila.

events.author: Assia Djebar
events.title: Date of death
events.description: Djebar died February 6th in Paris, France.

events.author: Étienne Balibar
events.title: Date of birth
events.description: Balibar was born in Avallon, France on April 23rd.

events.author: Étienne Balibar
events.title: Entered the École normale supérieure
events.description: Balibar entered the École normale supérieure (ENS) in Paris.

events.author: Étienne Balibar
events.title: Member of Communist Party
events.description: Balibar became a member of the French Communist Party.

events.author: Étienne Balibar
events.title: Student of Althusser
events.description: Balibar participated in Louis Althusser’s seminar on Marx’s Capital at the ENS and as a student of Althusser co-authored the book Lire le Capital.

events.author: Étienne Balibar
events.title: Expelled from the Communist Party
events.description: Balibar is expelled from the French Communist Party for critiquing the party's policy on immigration in an article.

events.author: Étienne Balibar
events.title: Completed PhD
events.description: Balibar completed his PhD in philosophy at Radboud University Nijmegen.

events.author: Étienne Balibar
events.title: Becomes Professor
events.description: Balibar became a Professor at the University of Paris X-Nanterre.

events.author: Étienne Balibar
events.title: New position
events.description: Balibar joined the University of California, Irvine.

events.author: Étienne Balibar
events.title: Becomes Professor Emeritus
events.description: Balibar became Professor Emeritus of moral and political philosophy at Paris X.

events.author: Gloria Wekker
events.title: Date of birth
events.description: Wekker was born in Paramaribo, Suriname on June 13th.

events.author: Gloria Wekker
events.title: Moved to the Netherlands
events.description: Wekker's family moved to the Netherlands from Suriname.

events.author: Gloria Wekker
events.title: Received master's degree
events.description: Wekker graduated and received her master's degree in Cultural Anthropology.

events.author: Gloria Wekker
events.title: Co-founded "Sister Outsider"
events.description: Wekker co-founded the black lesbian feminist group “Sister Outsider” together with Tania Leon, Tieneke Sumter and José Maas

events.author: Gloria Wekker
events.title: New position
events.description: Wekker becomes Policy Associate at the Office for the Coordination of Ethnic Minorities’ Affairs of Amsterdam, and wrote the Anti-Racism Policy Paper of the city

events.author: Gloria Wekker
events.title: Receives doctoral degree
events.description: Wekker receives her doctoral degree with the thesis I Am Gold Money (I Pass Through All Hands, But I Do Not Lose My Value): The Construction of Selves, Gender and Sexualities in a Female, Working-class, Afro- Surinamese Setting at the University of California, Los Angeles.

events.author: Gloria Wekker
events.title: New position
events.description: Wekker becomes Aletta-chair in Gender and Ethnicity at the Department of Women’s Studies, Utrecht University.

events.author: Gloria Wekker
events.title: New position
events.description: Wekker becomes Chair of the Diversity Committee at the University of Amsterdam.

events.author: Gloria Wekker
events.title: Active at political party BIJ1
events.description: Wekker becomes active in political party BIJ1. She was on the electoral list for the Dutch Parliamentary elections of 2017 and 2021, and the Amsterdam municipal elections of 2018.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Date of birth
events.description: Gilroy was born in London, UK on February 16th. He was born to intellectuals: renowned novelist and psychotherapist Beryl Gilroy (Guyanese) and scientist Patrick Gilroy (English).

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Obtained bachelor's degree
events.description: Gilroy finishes his bachelor's degree and obtains his degree at the University of Sussex.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Co-authors The Empire Strikes Back
events.description: Gilry co-authored The Empire Strikes Back with Routledge.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Completed PhD
events.description: Gilroy completed his PhD at Birmingham University under the supervision of Stuart Hall.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Published The Black Atlantic
events.description: Gilroy published The Black Atlantic with Verso Books.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: New position
events.description: Gilroy leaves the UK and takes up a post at Yale University, USA, where he became Professor of Sociology and African American Studies in 1999 and later Charlotte Marian Saden Professor of Sociology and African American Studies (2002 – 2005). He was also Director of Graduate studies (2000 – 2002) and later Chair (2002 – 2005) of Yale’s newly-created Department of African American Studies.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Return to London, UK
events.description: Gilroy leaves the USA, and returns to London, UK.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Elected as FRSL
events.description: Paul Gilroy was elected as a Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature (FRSL).

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Elected as FBA
events.description: Gilroy was elected a fellow of the British Academy, the United Kingdom's national academy for the humanities and social sciences.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Won the Holberg Prize
events.description: Gilroy won the €660,000 Holberg Prize

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Receives honorary doctorate
events.description: Gilroy receives a honorary doctorate from Goldsmiths College, University of London, UK.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Receives honorary doctorate
events.description: Gilroy receives a honorary doctorate from the University of Liège, Belgium.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Receives honorary doctorate
events.description: Gilroy receives a honorary doctorate from the University of Sussex, UK.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Elected as an international honorary member of the American Academy of Arts & Sciences
events.description: Gilory is elected as an international honorary member of the American Academy of Arts & Sciences.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Received the 50th Anniversary Fellowship of University of Sussex
events.description: Gilroy received the 50th Anniversary Fellowship of University of Sussex.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Position at South Bank Polytechnic, UK
events.description: Gilory taught at South Bank Polytechnic, UK.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Position at Essex University
events.description: Gilroy taught at Essex University, UK.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Position at Goldsmiths’ College, University of London
events.description: Gilroy taught at Goldsmiths’ College, University of London, where he became Professor of Sociology and Cultural Studies in 1995.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Position at the London School of Economics and Political Science
events.description: Gilroy was the first holder of the Anthony Giddens Professorship in Social Theory at the London School of Economics and Political Science (2005 – 2012), and he was Department Chair at the Sociology Department in 2012.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Position at King's College, London
events.description: Gilroy became Professor of American and English Literature at King’s College London.

events.author: Paul Gilroy
events.title: Position at University College London, UK
events.description: Gilroy became Professor of the Humanities at University College London, and founds the Sarah Parker Remond Centre for the Study of Racism & Racialisation.

events.author: Fatima El-Tayeb
events.title: Date of birth
events.description: El-Tayeb was born in Uelzen, Germany in 1966.

events.author: Fatima El-Tayeb
events.title: Received master's degree
events.description: El-Tayeb studied history and American studies at the University of Hamburg from 1990 to 1996. She received an MA in American Studies and Modern European History.

events.author: Fatima El-Tayeb
events.title: Completed PhD
events.description: El-Tayeb completed her PhD in History from the University of Hamburg.

events.author: Fatima El-Tayeb
events.title: Co-organized "Black European Studies" (BEST)
events.description: El-Tayeb became co-organizer of the research project "Black European Studies" (BEST) at the Johannes Gutenberg University in Mainz.

events.author: Fatima El-Tayeb
events.title: New position
events.description: El-Tayeb became curator of the project "Black Atlantic" in Berlin from 2003 to 2004.

events.author: Fatima El-Tayeb
events.title: New position
events.description: El-Tayeb became lecturer in "African American Culture and Film" at the University of California in San Diego, USA, where she was a member of the departments of Literature and Ethnic Studies and director of Critical Gender Studies.

events.author: Fatima El-Tayeb
events.title: Became Professor
events.description: El-Tayeb became Professor of Ethnicity, Race & Migration and Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies at the FASGSS Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies department at Yale University.

events.author: Sara Ahmed
events.title: Date of birth
events.description: Ahmed was born in Salford, UK on August 30th.

events.author: Sara Ahmed
events.title: New position
events.description: Ahmed became appointed Professor of Race and Cultural Studies, Goldsmiths, University of London.

events.author: Sara Ahmed
events.title: New position
events.description: Ahmed became inaugural director of the Centre for Feminist Research (CFR) at Goldsmiths.

events.author: Sara Ahmed
events.title: Resigned in protest
events.description: Ahmed resigned from her post at Goldsmiths in protest at the failure to deal with the sexual harassment of students by staff.

events.author: Sara Ahmed
events.title: Received the Kessler Award
events.description: Ahmed received the Kessler Award for contributions to the field of LGBTQ studies from CLAGS: The Center for LGBTQ Studies, CUNY.

events.author: Sara Ahmed
events.title: Receives honorary doctorate
events.description: Ahmed was awarded an honorary doctorate from Malmö University, Sweden.

events.author: Johny Pitts
events.title: Date of birth
events.description: Pitts was born in Sheffield, UK in 1982.

events.author: Johny Pitts
events.title: Met with writer Caryl Phillips
events.description: Pitss was inspired an supported by writer Caryl Phillips who helped him “navigate the treacherous terrain of class, race, and identity as a working-class black writer” (Pitts 2017). They first met in Brussels in 2017, where Johny Pitts experienced the close bonds and raport shared between writers.

events.author: Johny Pitts
events.title: Won multiple awards
events.description: Said and Barenboim worked on numerous other projects together and, in 2002, published Parallels and Paradoxes: Explorations in Music and Society, a compilation of their public conversations on music.
